etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Andrew Borde (c1490–1549), physician and author. From classical Latin perlustrāt-, past participial stem of perlustrāre to travel through, to scrutinize from per- + lustrāre

definitions: To travel through and inspect thoroughly; to survey comprehensively, especially in an official capacity.
To examine a document for the purpose of surveillance; to intercept and read correspondence passing through the post.
